comments.commentBody: "Our maw killed a b'ar when she was only three.  And two years later she shot herself an Injun."

I know exactly what you mean.

That is really funny about the Marina having the feel of a Fraternity/Sorority party. That is unfortunately also happening in New York.

Years ago, when I first lived in SF in the early 70s, the Marina was considered really dull, like where elderly Italian people went to die. I lived in North Beach, later in Cow Hollow. I remember going back on a visit about 20 years ago and being shocked to find a Pottery Barn on , of all places, Chestnut Street, so things were really changing from the old days of the mom and pop stores in that area. But fraternity/sorority types? That is too much. I was thinking of going back for a visit in January, but that just sounds so depressing I think I may just forget about it.
"Build slums for them to live in….'  That comment certainly resonates with what one sees when visiting Shanghai and any other large city in China. JUST what America needs to emulate…NOT!

Rent control (in NYC almost all regulated units fall under Rent Stabilization) is absolutely neccesary to preserve the middle class vibrancy of the city. Zoning laws are not an impediment to building and Bloomberg changed those zoning rules to cater to the developers. The affordable housing shortage is an artifical crisis created and perpetuated greedy developers. it's supply and demand, plain and simple. We need the housing and they control the supply. This should be DeBlasio's #1 concern.

Pilgrim, you are correct and it is an ongoing process. A new group flows into SFO every generation. Techies, yuppies, hippies.... all the way back to the gold rush (when the miners overran the Mormons).

JB - you must .not have lived in the Bay Area in the 80s. The whining sounded just the same.

This same process goes on in most great cities (NYC, Hong Kong, London, Singapore, Berlin, ...). It is what keeps them vital. Otherwise, you get cities like Detroit, or Baltimore, or Cleveland.
Just as the rent stabilization board in New York City is controlled by real estate interests. Maybe the NYT should investigate that before Santa Monica.

The main reason that home prices are so high in San Francisco (and to a lesser extent in NYC) is that the best places to build houses are under water. Both SF and NYC also have rent control, which protects the current renters, but raises prices far above market rates for newbies. SF also has been resistant to building up, a severe restriction in a place with limited real estate. If SF would permit every homeowner to add another story to the existing housing stock and to be able to rent it without any controls, the housing crisis would solve itself in a couple of years.
Maybe nothing. Maybe Orwell was right. Ayn Rand too.

Watch the city evolves? This city used to be a great place with all different people who do different things - imagine a boring city where everyone does the same thing in the same field, that is where this is heading.

@jacrane

"This business has always been run as a religious business. "

I have no idea what this means.

The company's website says, "Hobby Lobby is considered a leader in the arts and crafts industry. We have 578 stores across the nation that average 55,000 square feet and offer more than 67,000 crafting and home decor products. Hobby Lobby is listed as a major private corporation in Forbes and Fortunes list of America's largest private companies, and our company carries no long-term debt."

Perhaps you just don't understand that private or public, Hobby Lobby is a for-profit corporation. Having chosen to incorporate, rather than to remain a private business, the owners of Hobby Lobby are just as entitled to their religious beliefs and views as any other Americans, but they are equally restricted to the legal obligations of corporate entities, and must follow all legal injunctions against discrimination. The private beliefs of the Green family do not exempt them from such injunctions.

We do not live in a theocracy. If Mr Green wants to impose his religious views on his employees, he should relocate to someplace like Iran.
Individual rights supported by individual responsibility….
So people are okay with Citizens United only if it is used to elect statists and UFT puppets to office?
Wait, you must be from California?  Naturally!
It's the smartest thing that man ever said.

Einstein America

What is this all leading to? Seems very, very creepy.

***
The good news is that we haven't arrived anywhere yet and the road is a very long one. The voices in this video raise excellent points about the future.

The NSA is nowhere near the point where the government is all knowing. If anything, it is is only able to capture a tiny percentage of the data available.

Congress is going to have to take this one on. The White House is not up to the task.
Andrea, I envy your optimism, but I fear this is only the tip of the iceberg.

Eric R Tucson

Andrea, I envy your optimism, but I fear this is only the tip of the iceberg.

***
It's not optimism. If you do some basic research on big data mining techniques, you'll see that even the best technologists are able to capture only a very limited amount of data and/or make sense of it. The models for all this are still being developed and fine-tuned.

Remember, the government isn't limited to tweets or Facebook postings. It's looking at *everything*. It's like trying to capture and analyze several dust particles among all the trillions++ blowing in the air.

The privacy questions are legitimate, and I'm grateful they are being asked. I just wonder how much the NSA is actually able to do at this point.

What is this all leading to? Seems very, very creepy.

President Obama, Republican and Democrat politicians should be protecting the personal and financial data of the American people.

Today in NYTimes:
ID Verification Lagging on Health Care Website
By ROBERT PEAR
Published: November 25, 2013

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/11/26/us/id-verification-lagging-on-health-c...

Similar initiative in England-

National 'virtual ID card' scheme set for launch (Is there anything that could possibly go wrong?)

Central online identity scheme 'will be a target for criminals'

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/national-virtual-id-card-s...
David Dinkins always was tone-deaf. I'd feel much more confident if de Blasio had had a different mentor -- Dan Pat Moynihan, say.
Something like 21% of the electorate bothered to vote.
Agree with you and believe the people DeBlasio proposes to tax are much better able to shoulder this tax than poor middle-class commuters from Jersey and the Island.

It's not taxing the rich to give money "to the poor". It's taxing the rich so that all New York families, which include many families that many people in this country would consider rich, can send their kids to public pre-school. It certainly includes the middle-class.

There are research studies showing substantial lifetime gains for children who attend pre-school. The rich who run businesses need a qualified work force. This is one way to get them that. Having a qualified work force makes the rich richer.

Are we so selfish as a society that the people who can afford $multi-million apartments won't chip in a drop more so that kids can go to pre-school? 100 years from now, people will look back at those people the way we look at slaveholders now. The rich scream about high taxes, but in terms of Federal rates, the highest marginal rate was 70% under Nixon, 50% under Reagan, 39.6% under Clinton, 35% under Bush and Obama up until this year and now it's back up to 39.6%, still far lower than it was under the conservative hero, Ronald Reagan.
Not until the unwealthy get sufficiently violent and unruly.  I'll be waiting patiently.  It will still take a while for rents to drop.
Voters of New York, welcome back to the 1970s.  At least you can afford to live in the city again

Florida? Are you kidding? I once told somebody I met at a party that I was going to Florida the next day to visit a relative -- and he promptly stopped talking to me.

Rich, by the way, in case you don't know, is somebody making more than $500,000 a year. Does that sound poor to you?

Hi Joseph,

You might consider listening to an episode of the This American Life podcast that deals with early childhood education.

http://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/477/getting-away-...

Even the most conservative states understand the benefits of a functional public pre-k system. Think about Georgia or Oklahoma.

To me, it seems like a good and workable idea.

The Federal government's own studies have shown that by fourth grade there is no discernible difference between children who attended a Pre-K and those who didn't scholastically. Yet there remains a push to create them. It's more like free day care and and another opportunity to indoctrinate the children into the party pushing this stuff's doctrines.

Bevan, what kind of study did you think the "Center for Public Education" would come up with? Here's a study for you - in Sweden and Finland, academics do not begin until age seven. And how well do Swedish and Finish students do compared to other countries?

And with respect to "welfare-queen ranting," it is you, sir, who has racial issues, not me. Mothers who cannot find the public library are unfortunately represented very well in all races.

Increase taxes on "the rich" for mandatory "pre-K" (a/k/a nursery school) in a city that has many districts that are already at 110% capacity, and are in areas that there is no place to build additional classrooms.

Moreover, there is not a speck of evidence that "pre-K" (a/k/a nursery school) turns kids into better students when they have mothers who know five places where to buy a 50" TV, but cannot find the nearest public library.

A bad idea and an unworkable idea.

Ahhhhhh! Reduce salaries and reduce payrolls of these agencies. Get staffing down to the point where, if nothing gets done, there are only a few people in the room who could possibly be to blame.

I love it!

I was near a county building today and approached a worker to ask a benign question...along the lines of "Do you have the correct time?"

Before I could get a word out, he waved me off and said (with a full mouth) "I'm on lunch."

Beautiful.

@Barrett

Israel will not exist without US support and could never confront its adversaries as it does without belief that we will fight to protect It. If you don't believe that, please convince AIPAC and save us all time.

Each of the provocations, assassinations, illegal settlements etc that Israel endeavors is done with US monetary aid and with full knowledge that, like a protective big brother, the US stands ready to pick Israel up and to fight powers that Israel itself cannot fend off.

Where did Israel gets its nuclear technology and from whom does it continue to get diplomatic cover for the same? The US.

From whom does Israel receive its air defense (active right now) that enables its bellicose posture? The US.

States bigoted to one religion deserve each other. Let Israel and the Saudis cozy up. They deserve each other.

It's about time that "some daylight" existed between the US and Israel and President Obama should be applauded for his effort to break from the past. Israel has proven that it will always go its own way; whether in the secret development of its own nuclear weapons program, the continuation of the building of settlements on the West Bank, or talks, or the lack thereof, with the Palestinians. The US can least afford to get involved in another conflict especially when a peaceful solution might exist.

Out here in flyover country aka The Rust Belt, we pay our interns -- even those who work at non-profits.  Leadership Lorain County, with support from local foundations, places interns with a wide range of non-profit organizations each summer.  LLC pays half of the $10/hour salary -- the organization pays the other half.  LLC provides initial screening and ongoing support for the interns -- the organization gets a hardworking, dedicated, smart employee for the summer who brings essential skills and enthusiasm to the work.  It's a winner for everyone involved!
